examples: he gave up tobacco and alcohol with ease
the guitar's versatility and ease of handling

verb.description: Make (something unpleasant, painful, or intense) less serious or severe.
examples: a huge road-building program to ease congestion
I eased down the slope with care
the boat eased away from the harbor
the pilot eased the throttle back

phrases: she was never quite at ease with Phil
I could tell by our team's attitude that they seemed to be totally at ease when they took the field.
With Will it's so easy not to feel intimidated because he puts you at ease.
Now vulnerable people can feel more at ease knowing that recruits are signing up to stop doorstep con-artists.
The master of ceremonies will welcome each of the contestants in turn, set them at their ease, and introduced the musical item that each will render.
origin: Middle English: from Old French aise, based on Latin adjacens lying close by, present participle of adjacere. The verb is originally from Old French aisier, from the phrase a aise at ease; in later use from the noun.
